marketNews.title: The Fed Holds Interest Rate, Strengthens Higher for Longer Signal
marketNews.content: The US Federal Reserve decided to keep its policy interest rate target in the range of 5.25% to 5.5% during its meeting on Wednesday (May 1), in line with consensus expectations. In that meeting, Fed Chair Jerome Powell signaled that the Fed will not raise rates further, but he also noted that higher-than-expected inflation data for the first three months of 2024 could cause rate cuts to be slower than initially projected. On Thursday (May 2), probability analysis from the CME FedWatch Tool showed that the market expects the Fed’s first rate cut to start in September 2024, with a probability of 56.4%, down from 58% on April 25, 2024. The narrative of a higher-for-longer US rate environment triggered foreign outflows from Indonesian equities and bonds. In the past month, the IDX index recorded foreign outflows of IDR 20.31 trillion as of April 30, 2024. As of April 29, 2024, the Indonesian bond market saw foreign outflows of IDR 16.73 trillion over the past month. In addition to rate policy, the Fed also announced that it will reduce the pace of its balance-sheet runoff to US$25 billion per month starting June 1, 2024, down from the previous US$60 billion. Mortgage-backed securities issuance will remain permitted at a cap of US$35 billion per month. This step aims to ensure the financial system retains sufficient reserves, avoiding a shortage similar to that experienced in 2019 during the last round of quantitative tightening by the Fed.

marketNews.title: Key Takeaway
marketNews.content: The Fed’s signal to postpone US rate cuts may keep expectations for higher-for-longer Bank Indonesia rates. Previously, in the April 2024 Governor’s Board meeting, Bank Indonesia raised the BI Rate by 25 basis points to 6.25% to curb rupiah depreciation against the US dollar. In response to the stronger higher-for-longer signal, the yield on the 10-year Indonesian government bond rose by 10 basis points to 7.278% on Thursday (May 2). Over the past month, the yield has increased by 63 basis points. Persistently high rates for an extended period could pressure several sectors, including: Property and automotive – weaker demand due to higher mortgage (KPR) and motor vehicle loan (KKB) rates; Construction – high debt levels increase interest-bearing costs; Banking – higher cost of funds amid slowing DPK growth. Most banks reported higher cost of funds in 1Q24, squeezing net interest margins, consistent with industry data from OJK.

marketNews.title: Indonesia Consumer Price Index April 2024
marketNews.content: According to the Indonesian Central Statistics Agency (BPS), the consumer price index (CPI) inflation in Indonesia reached 3.0% year-on-year in April 2024 (versus 3.05% in March 2024), slightly below the consensus forecast of 3.06% YoY. On a month-to-month basis, inflation was 0.25% in April (versus 0.52% in March), the lowest level in three months but above the consensus of 0.21% MoM. Core inflation stood at 1.82% YoY (versus 1.77% YoY in March), exceeding the consensus of 1.76% YoY and marking the highest level in five months.

marketNews.title: Indonesia Manufacturing PMI April 2024
marketNews.content: S&P Global reported that Indonesia’s manufacturing Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) fell to 52.9 in April 2024 (down from 54.2 in March 2024), indicating that factory activity has expanded for the 32nd consecutive month.

marketNews.title: Indonesia International Tourist Arrivals March 2024
marketNews.content: The Indonesian Central Statistics Agency (BPS) recorded that foreign tourist arrivals to Indonesia reached 1.04 million in March 2024, a decline of 1.91% month-on-month but an increase of 19.86% year-on-year. Over the three-month period of 2024, foreign tourist arrivals rose 25.43% YoY to 3.03 million, representing 17.8% of the government target of 17 million.

marketNews.title: Microsoft Announces $1.7 Billion Investment in Indonesia
marketNews.content: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella announced that Microsoft will invest US$1.7 billion in Indonesia over the next four years, focusing on cloud infrastructure and artificial intelligence (AI). The company views Southeast Asia as a potential hub for AI product development. According to a study by global consulting firm Kearney, AI could contribute nearly US$1 trillion to Southeast Asia’s GDP by 2030, with Indonesia expected to capture about US$366 billion of that amount.

marketNews.title: Vidio Targets 8 Million Paying Subscribers Ahead of IPO
marketNews.content: Surya Citra Media’s subsidiary Vidio aims to double its paying subscriber base to 8 million within the next two to three years ahead of a planned initial public offering. CEO Sutanto Hartono said the company will pursue an IPO once market sentiment improves. Media Partners Asia data for 2023 shows Vidio has the highest number of paying subscribers in Indonesia, with a streaming revenue share of 17%, second only to Netflix’s 26% share, which commands higher subscription fees.

tickerNews.title: BMRI Reports Q1 2024 Net Profit Below Expectations
tickerNews.content: Bank Mandiri reported net profit of IDR 12.7 trillion (down 20.6% quarter-on-quarter, up 1.1% year-on-year) in 1Q24, representing 21.7% of the FY24 consensus estimate. Net interest income rose to IDR 24.2 trillion (+0.7% QoQ, +5.1% YoY). The quarterly profit decline was driven by a 261% QoQ increase in provision expenses, despite a 2.6% YoY decrease. Operationally, loan growth was +19.1% YoY, well above management guidance of +13-15% and the Bank Indonesia/OJK industry target of +9-12%. The loan-to-deposit ratio rose to 89.7% (vs. 84.9% in 1Q23 and 86.8% in 4Q23). Net interest margin fell to 5.07% (vs. 5.4% in 1Q23 and 5.15% in 4Q23), below the guidance range of 5.3-5.5%.

tickerNews.title: ADRO Reports Q1 2024 Net Profit and Revenue Decline
tickerNews.content: Adaro Energy Indonesia posted a net profit of US$374 million (down 11.4% QoQ, down 18.3% YoY) in 1Q24, equal to 35.7% of the FY24 consensus estimate. Revenue was US$1.4 billion (down 6.1% QoQ, down 21.5% YoY), representing 27.1% of the consensus. The revenue decline was caused by a 24% YoY drop in average selling price, while coal sales volume increased 4.8% YoY to 16.5 million tonnes. Gross profit margin rose to 43.5% (vs. 35.7% in 4Q23 and 41.5% in 1Q23) as cost of sales fell (-17.4% QoQ, -24.3% YoY). Coal production volume grew 15% YoY to 18.1 million tonnes, with a strip ratio of 3.66x (vs. 4.56x in 4Q23 and 3.59x in 1Q23).

tickerNews.title: ACES Reports Q1 2024 Net Profit Growth
tickerNews.content: Ace Hardware Indonesia reported net profit of IDR 205 billion (+29.3% YoY) in 1Q24, equal to 23.4% of the FY24 consensus estimate (vs. IDR 20.7 billion in 1Q23). Revenue grew 17% YoY to IDR 1.9 trillion, driven by same-store sales growth of 13.2% YoY, the highest cumulative 1Q same-store growth since the pandemic. Cost of sales increased 17% YoY, keeping gross profit margin stable at 48.5%. Operating profit margin rose to 13.3% (+136 basis points YoY) as operating expenses fell, resulting in net profit margin of 10.3% (+98 basis points YoY).

tickerNews.title: INDF Reports Q1 2024 Net Profit and Revenue Details
tickerNews.content: Indofood Sukses Makmur posted net profit of approximately IDR 2.5 trillion (down 36% YoY, up 130% QoQ) in 1Q24, equal to 24% of the FY24 consensus estimate and 25% of the Stockbit FY24 estimate. Revenue reached IDR 30.8 trillion (+1% YoY, +11% QoQ), representing 26% of the Stockbit estimate and below consensus, with a gross profit margin of 34.1% (vs. 31.1% in 1Q23 and 35.5% in 4Q23). Operationally, INDF’s operating profit increased to IDR 5.9 trillion (+12% YoY, +7% QoQ), matching our expectation of 30% of the Stockbit estimate, though below the consensus expectation of 26% of the consensus. The lower net profit was pressured by a significant foreign exchange loss of IDR 1.2 trillion (versus a foreign exchange gain of IDR 1.5 trillion in 1Q23).

tickerNews.title: ICBP Reports Q1 2024 Net Profit Decline
tickerNews.content: Indofood CBP Sukses Makmur reported net profit of approximately IDR 2.4 trillion (down 41% YoY) in 1Q24, an improvement from a net loss of IDR 69 billion in 4Q23. The result equals 24% of the FY24 consensus estimate and is below expectations. Revenue grew to IDR 19.9 trillion (+4% YoY, +20% QoQ), representing 27% of the consensus. Operating profit rose 12% YoY and 33% QoQ, but net profit fell year-on-year due to foreign exchange loss.

tickerNews.title: PTBA Reports Q1 2024 Net Profit Below Expectations
tickerNews.content: Bukit Asam posted net profit of IDR 791 billion (down 66% QoQ, down 32% YoY) in 1Q24, achieving only 15.5% of the FY24 consensus estimate. Revenue fell to IDR 9.4 trillion (down 12.5% QoQ, down 5.5% YoY), roughly in line with 24.6% of the consensus, while sales volume still grew year-on-year (+10.2%) despite a 3% QoQ decline. Gross profit margin compressed to 15.1% (vs. 30.1% in 4Q23 and 20.7% in 1Q23) as cost of sales rose to IDR 8 trillion (+6.3% QoQ, +1.1% YoY). Coal production volume increased 7.4% YoY to 7.3 million tonnes.
